Character Name: This is what the dungeon will scream when you mess up.
Your chosen identifier for fame, infamy, or the obituary.
Names have power. This one mostly attracts danger.
Shorter names are easier to shout during combat.
Legendary heroes start here. So do corpses.
Changing this later will not change your fate.
This is how NPCs will pretend to remember you.
Pick wisely. The dungeon never forgets.
Your chosen identifier. The label that will appear on kill feeds, tombstones, and post-mortem loot audits.
Pick something heroic, ominous, or ironic. The dungeon prefers irony. Also easier to chant.
Species: Your biological or mechanical excuse for your stats.
Determines how society judges you before you speak.
Some species get darkvision. Some get stereotypes.
You did not choose this lightly. Or at all.
Innate traits included. Warranty not provided.
Yes, this affects roleplay. No, it won’t save you.
Your ancestry is now a rules interaction.
Your biological template, complete with perks, flaws, and cultural baggage you will absolutely validate.
Includes gait, posture, and footwear expectations. Yes, I noticed how you walk.
Class: Your job title in a world with terrible benefits.
Determines how you solve problems and create new ones.
This is why the party expects certain things from you.
You are now locked into a playstyle. Mostly.
Every class thinks theirs is the hardest.
Your combat philosophy in one word.
Your primary method of solving problems until it stops working.
Determines whether you charge, scheme, pray, or dramatically monologue before failure.
Subclass: This is where flavor becomes mechanical.
You picked a lane. Swerving is discouraged.
This is why two fighters are never the same.
Because you wanted your mistakes to feel bespoke.
Level: A numerical measure of how much trouble you can survive.
Higher is better. Lower is deadlier.
This number terrifies monsters and DMs alike.
Represents experience, luck, and plot armor.
Every level is earned in blood or paperwork.
You grow stronger. The dungeon adapts.
A rough estimate of how many disasters you’ve endured without quitting.
Higher numbers mean better odds, not better judgment.
XP: A tally of how close you are to improvement.
Earned through violence, cleverness, or exploitation.
Higher XP means closer to power spikes.
Numbers go up. So do threats.
Progress points awarded for risk-taking and emotional damage.
Spend enough of these and the dungeon pretends to respect you.
AC: How hard you are to hit. Not how hard you are to kill.
Armor Class: the enemy’s problem, allegedly.
Does not protect against bad decisions.
How hard you are to hit, not how smart it was to be there.
Boots, armor, reflexes—yes, all factored in. I see everything.
Proficiency Bonus: Adds confidence to things you claim to know.
Scales automatically. Enjoy the illusion of growth.
This applies more often than you think.
A small number with big implications.
You’re better at stuff now. Allegedly.
One bonus to rule them all.
Strength: How hard you hit and how much you lift.
Dexterity users pretend this is optional.
Raw force output and door-negotiation skill.
Correlates strongly with stomping. Not judging. Noticing.
Dexterity: Speed, balance, and not getting stabbed.
High Dex solves many problems quietly.
This is why you act first.
Clean pivots. Flexible ankles. Don’t blush.
Constitution: How hard you are to kill. Again.
A boring stat until it isn’t.
How long your body refuses to give up.
Includes bone density and blister tolerance.
Intelligence: Determines how much you know afterward.
Low INT characters still have ideas. Sometimes.
Knowing where to step. Knowing when not to.
Wisdom: Perception and insight depend on this.
This is not intelligence. Stop arguing.
You *felt* the trap. You ignored it.
Charisma: Force of personality and social gravity.
High CHA gets away with things.
Your ability to sell bad ideas convincingly.
Eye contact helps. So does confident posture.
Hit Points: How much damage you can absorb before panic.
Zero is bad. Negative is worse.
HP is a suggestion, not a promise.
Once this hits zero, posture becomes irrelevant.
Equipment: Everything you own that hasn’t been stolen yet.
Most items are situational. Situations happen.
Coins: Abstract wealth with very real weight.
Money solves problems until it doesn’t.
Copper is annoying. Platinum is suspicious.
Thieves Tools: Ah yes, the official kit for touching things you absolutely should not be touching. If it clicks, great. If it snaps, you’re about to meet consequences.
These tools exist to turn locked doors into suggestions and traps into learning experiences. Mostly the learning kind.
Congratulations, you brought the toolkit that says ‘I definitely planned to be here illegally.’
Tinkers Tools: For when you look at a perfectly functional object and think, ‘I can make this worse, but interesting.’
A box of bits, wires, and poor decisions. Results may include gadgets, explosions, or both.
You use these to invent things no one asked for and everyone will blame you for.
Carpenters Tools: Wood goes in, furniture comes out. Or splinters. Often splinters.
These tools allow you to turn trees into doors, bridges, and objects enemies will hide behind.
Because sometimes the dungeon needs a table, and sometimes it needs a barricade built in a panic.
Smiths Tools: Fire, metal, and the confidence to hit something until it becomes useful.
You make weapons here. And armor. And occasionally unrecognizable slag.
If it’s heavy, hot, and dangerous, you’re probably doing it right.
Weavers Tools: For creating cloth, rope, and the illusion that you understand textiles.
You turn thread into clothing and clothing into a reason people stop staring.
Yes, this includes fancy cloaks. No, it does not make you fashionable by default.
Wood Carvers Tools: You remove wood until something recognizable remains. Ideally not your fingers.
Perfect for decorative items, holy symbols, or ominous figurines that worry the party.
A slow, patient craft in a world that keeps trying to kill you.
Brewers Supplies: You make alcohol. Sometimes it’s good. Sometimes it’s technically poison.
These supplies turn water into morale, courage, and bad decisions.
Every batch answers the question: ‘How flammable is this?’
Alchemists Supplies: Liquids, powders, and a near-religious faith in trial and error.
You mix things together and hope the result heals someone instead of dissolving them.
Warning: side effects may include smoke, smells, and unexpected sentience.
Artificer: A spellcaster who looked at magic and said, ‘This needs more hardware.’
You solve problems with tools, intellect, and devices that beep ominously.
When something breaks, you fix it. When something works, you upgrade it until it breaks.
Warforged: A living construct: proof that someone once thought free will was optional.
You do not eat, sleep, or breathe—yet somehow still feel existential dread.
Built for war, now stuck managing inventory and emotions.
Lawful: You follow rules. Even bad ones. Especially bad ones.
Predictable, reliable, and deeply confused when chaos works.
You believe order solves problems. Reality disagrees occasionally.
Neutral: You stand firmly in the middle while everyone else sets things on fire.
Your moral compass points toward ‘it depends.’
Chaotic: You treat rules as optional side quests.
Impulse-driven, unpredictable, and shockingly effective at causing incidents.
You believe freedom is worth the collateral damage.
Alignment (etc.): A loose philosophical guideline everyone argues about and regularly ignores.
This describes your intent, not your results. The results are usually worse.
Think of it as vibes, not enforcement.
Proficiency: Congratulations, you now fail with confidence.
Initiative: Reaction speed when things go wrong.
Speed: How quickly you can reposition or retreat.
Size: Your physical footprint in the world.
Bigger targets wear bigger boots. Statistics only.
Passive Perception: You saw the floor scuff marks. You chose to ignore them.
Weapons: Grip matters. Balance matters. Feet planted—yes, like that.
Damage: Transfer of force begins at the ground up.
Features: Use them or be judged silently.
Background Features: Proof you existed before the violence.
Old habits show in how you stand.
Species Traits: Includes stance, stride, and balance tendencies.
Spellcasting: Reality bending through confidence and hand motions.
Foot placement during casting is… adequate.
Spell Ability: The stat you use to bully the universe.
Conviction helps. So does stable footing.
Save DC: How hard it is to resist your nonsense.
Authority starts from the ground up.
Somatic: Yes, including the feet. Don’t ask.
Concentration: Try not to shift your weight so much.
